prior_works.title: Verifiable Reinforcement Learning via Policy Extraction (VIPER)
prior_works.authors: Osbert Bastani, Yewen Pu, Armando Solar-Lezama
prior_works.role: Motivation and prior approach to interpretable policies
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced extracting decision-tree policies for interpretability and verifiability in discrete settings, motivating the focus on decision trees as controllers and highlighting the gap for continuous-time safety verification that this paper addresses.

prior_works.title: What’s Decidable About Hybrid Automata?
prior_works.authors: Thomas A. Henzinger, Peter W. Kopke, Anuj Puri, Pravin Varaiya
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established fundamental undecidability and complexity boundaries for hybrid systems, providing the conceptual basis for proving undecidability and PSPACE-completeness results for decision-tree-controlled continuous-time systems.

prior_works.title: Bounded Model Checking
prior_works.authors: Armin Biere, Alessandro Cimatti, Edmund M. Clarke, Yunshan Zhu
prior_works.role: Verification technique for discrete-time finite-horizon properties
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the standard SAT/SMT-based method for finite-horizon verification in discrete-time systems, underpinning the paper’s observation that discrete-time decision-tree policies can be verified via BMC while motivating a direct continuous-time alternative.

prior_works.title: SpaceEx: Scalable Verification of Hybrid Systems
prior_works.authors: Goran Frehse, Colas Le Guernic, Antoine Girard, Thao Dang, Olivier Maler, et al.
prior_works.role: Algorithmic inspiration (set-based reachability with guard handling)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneered scalable set-based flowpipe computation with guard-based splitting in hybrid automata, directly informing the idea of propagating reachable sets through decision-tree nodes viewed as guards.

prior_works.title: Flow*: An Analyzer for Non-linear Hybrid Systems
prior_works.authors: Xin Chen, Erika Ábrahám, Sriram Sankaranarayanan
prior_works.role: Algorithmic technique for continuous-time set propagation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Developed Taylor-model-based over-approximations for nonlinear ODE reachability with event handling, influencing the paper’s continuous-time, set-propagation framework adapted to decision-tree policies.

prior_works.title: Reachability of Uncertain Linear Systems Using Zonotopes
prior_works.authors: Antoine Girard, Colas Le Guernic, Oded Maler
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced efficient zonotope-based reachability that underpins modern set-based approximations, a core component of the paper’s approach to propagate sets through controller-induced partitions.

prior_works.title: Hybridization Methods for the Analysis of Nonlinear Systems
prior_works.authors: Eugene Asarin, Olivier Bournez, Thao Dang, Oded Maler
prior_works.role: Conceptual precedent (piecewise partitioning and guard-driven analysis)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Proposed analyzing nonlinear dynamics via piecewise partitions and guard-based transitions, conceptually mirroring the paper’s exploitation of decision boundaries in trees as guards for set propagation.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—proving hardness results and presenting a first direct continuous-time safety verifier for decision-tree controllers—sits at the intersection of interpretable policy design and hybrid-systems verification. VIPER established decision trees as a practical, verifiable representation for learned policies in discrete settings, motivating the need to carry such verification into continuous time where many control systems operate. The theoretical backdrop is anchored by Henzinger et al.’s decidability landscape for hybrid automata, which provides a template for deriving undecidability and PSPACE-completeness results when controllers induce mode switches through state-dependent guards—exactly how decision-tree tests behave in closed loop.
Methodologically, the work borrows from and specializes classic set-based reachability. SpaceEx and Flow* exemplify flowpipe construction with careful handling of guards and events; these techniques inspire the paper’s key insight to treat decision nodes as guard hyperplanes and to split and propagate over-approximations accordingly. Foundational set representations such as zonotopes (Girard et al.) supply the computational substrate for scalable set propagation. Hybridization methods (Asarin et al.) further reinforce the idea that piecewise partitioning and guard-driven reasoning are effective for nonlinear systems—a paradigm that the paper adapts to the controller side rather than the plant. Finally, while bounded model checking offers an effective path for discrete-time finite-horizon verification, its limitations in continuous time clarify the paper’s niche: delivering guarantees without time discretization by leveraging the structural regularity of decision trees.
